headline.main: The Bagger in L.A.: It is Written, Deconstructed and Annotated

docs.snippet: We will pull out of Los Angeles today, not pretending that the season was a big winner - an early, unstoppable leader for the race will do that. But the season had its share of charms: Kate Winslet asking nicely for an Oscar and getting one, Sean ...
docs.lead_paragraph: We will pull out of Los Angeles today, not pretending that the season was a big winner - an early, unstoppable leader for the race will do that. But the season had its share of charms: Kate Winslet asking nicely for an Oscar and getting one, Sean and Mickey managing to compete while maintaining both decorum and fraternity, and the wholesale decency of the "Slumdog Millionaire" crew. (One of the benefits of doing business with a good person like Danny Boyle is that when you need them to imitate a human being for the awards campaign, they don't have to get their frontal lobes replaced.)
docs.abstract: We will pull out of Los Angeles today, not pretending that the season was a big winner - an early, unstoppable leader for the race will do that. headline.main: The Bagger in L.A.: Some Charms Along the Way

docs.lead_paragraph: Celebrity gossip, it seems, will never go out of style. At least, that's what Josh Berman and Colin Digiaro, co-founders of MySpace, are hoping with their latest venture.

headline.main: MySpace Founders Roll Out Red Carpet for DailyFill

docs.snippet: Its depictions of filth and brutality fueled angry blogging and stray street protests. It drew unusually intense scrutiny, for everything from how much its child actors were paid to what the composer A. R. Rahman would wear to the Oscars. But on M...
docs.lead_paragraph: Its depictions of filth and brutality fueled angry blogging and stray street protests. It drew unusually intense scrutiny, for everything from how much its child actors were paid to what the composer A. R. Rahman would wear to the Oscars. But on Monday, as India woke up to news of the spectacular wins by ''Slumdog Millionaire'' at the Academy Awards, this movie-mad country went ''Jai Ho.'' The movie's victory was embraced as India's own.

headline.main: Indians Embrace the Triumph of 'Slumdog' as a Victory for Their Country

docs.snippet: Ratings for the 81st Annual Academy Awards on Sunday night were up significantly over last year's telecast, the least-watched Oscars on record. Nielsen's preliminary estimates show an average of 36.3 million viewers tuned in to the three- hour-plu...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ratings for the 81st Annual Academy Awards on Sunday night were up significantly over last year's telecast, the least-watched Oscars on record. Nielsen's preliminary estimates show an average of 36.3 million viewers tuned in to the three- hour-plus awards show on ABC, a 13 percent increase over the 32 million who watched in 2008. Oscar ratings are down considerably from an all-time high of 55 million in 1998, when ''Titanic'' dominated the awards; two years ago 40.2 million viewers tuned in. ABC easily won the night over all, while Fox was runner-up with live Nascar coverage throughout prime time (9.7 million). CBS earned third place with ''60 Minutes'' at 7 (9.2 million) and ''The Amazing Race'' at 8 (7.8 million), followed by repeats of ''Cold Case'' (6.9 million) and ''The Unit'' (5.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC finished in fourth place.

byline.original: By BENJAMIN TOFF; Compiled by Dave Itzkoff

docs.snippet: An article on Monday about the Academy Awards ceremony misstated part of a comment by Danny Boyle, director of “Slumdog Millionaire,” in some editions. Mr. Boyle, saluting the people of Mumbai, where the film is set, said, “You dwarf even th...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the Academy Awards ceremony misstated part of a comment by Danny Boyle, director of “Slumdog Millionaire,” in some editions. Mr. Boyle, saluting the people of Mumbai, where the film is set, said, “You dwarf even this guy,” referring to the Oscar statuette — not “You dwarf even the sky.”.
